turns.unknown_model_response:
Below is a **worked‑example** that translates the “deaths‑per‑energy‑unit” figures into the **annual number of expected deaths** for two plants that are the same size on paper – ≈ 1 GW (electric) of installed capacity.

---

## 1.  Choose a “typical” plant size and output  

| Parameter | Coal‑fired plant | Nuclear plant |
|-----------|------------------|---------------|
| **Name‑plate capacity** | 1 GW (electric) | 1 GW (electric) |
| **Typical capacity factor** (average % of time the plant runs at full power) | 0.75 – 0.85 (most modern coal plants) | 0.90 – 0.95 (large baseload reactors) |
| **Annual electricity produced** | 1 GW × 0.80 × 8 876 h ≈ 7.0 TWh / yr | 1 GW × 0.93 × 8 876 h ≈ 8.2 TWh / yr |

*The exact output depends on the plant’s design, fuel quality, local grid demand, and forced outages. The numbers above are the midpoint of the ranges most often quoted in the literature.*

---

## 2.  Apply the life‑cycle death‑rate estimates  

| Source | Deaths per TWh (mid‑point of the ranges in the table above) | Annual electricity (TWh) | **Estimated deaths per year** |
|--------|-----------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Coal** (air‑pollution‑dominated) | **≈ 30 deaths / TWh** (mid‑point of 24–40) | 7.0 TWh | **≈ 210 deaths / yr** |
| **Nuclear** (radiation‑accident‑dominated) | **≈ 0.055 deaths / TWh** (mid‑point of 0.04–0.07) | 8.2 TWh | **≈ 0.45 deaths / yr** |

### How the numbers are obtained  

*Coal*:  

\[
30\;\frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} \times 7.0\;\text{TWh} = 210\;\text{deaths per year}
\]

*The 30 deaths/TWh figure already includes **all** mortality associated with the coal life‑cycle:  
  • **Air‑pollution health impacts** (the overwhelming share, ≈ 80 %).  
  • **Mining‑related accidents** (≈ 10 %).  
  • **Plant‑operational accidents** (<< 1 %).  
  • **Fuel‑cycle waste handling** (<< 1 %).*

*The 210‑death figure is therefore an *average* expectation for a plant that operates continuously under typical modern emission controls (e.g., electrostatic precipitators, flue‑gas desulfurisation). If the plant has lax controls, the rate can climb to > 50 deaths/TWh, pushing the annual total above 300 deaths.*

*Nuclear*:  

\[
0.055\;\frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} \times 8.2\;\text{TWh} \approx 0.45\;\text{deaths per year}
\]

*The 0.055 deaths/TWh value is dominated by the **rare, high‑impact accidents** that have occurred in the entire history of commercial nuclear power (Chernobyl, Fukushima, Three‑Mile Island). When those accidents are spread over the total global nuclear electricity generated to date, the per‑TWh fatality rate works out to roughly 0.04–0.07 deaths/TWh.*

*If a plant operates **without** any major accident, its “routine” contribution to mortality is **≈ 0.001 deaths/TWh** (mostly from very low‑level occupational radiation exposure and uranium‑mining injuries). In that case a 1‑GW reactor would cause **≈ 0.008 deaths per year**, i.e. a chance of one death roughly once every 125 years.*

| **Estimated total deaths from the plant (all life‑cycle stages)** | **≈  800 deaths / yr** (≈ 30 deaths/TWh × 27 TWh) | See calculation below |

### How the 800‑death figure is obtained

1. **Start with the life‑cycle mortality rate for modern, emission‑controlled coal**  
   *Most peer‑reviewed life‑cycle assessments (LCAs) for coal in the United States converge on **≈ 30 deaths per TWh** of electricity produced** (range 24–40).  
   *The dominant component (≈ 80 % of the total) is **premature mortality from ambient air‑pollution** (PM₂.₅, SO₂, NOₓ, mercury). The remaining ≈ 20 % comes from mining accidents, occupational injuries, and the very small risk of a plant‑scale accident.*

2. **Multiply by the plant’s annual output**  

   \[
   30\;\frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} \times 27\;\text{TWh} \;=\; 810\;\text{deaths/yr}
   \]

3. **Round to a sensible number** → **≈ 800 deaths per year**.

> **Bottom line:** a single 3.5‑GW coal complex that supplies power to roughly 5 million U.S. households is statistically linked to **about eight hundred premature deaths each year** when the full health impact of its emissions is accounted for.
